headline.main: 12 NATURALIZED CITIZENS TO GET MEDAL OF LIBERTY

results.snippet: Twelve prominent Americans, 11 men and 1 woman, all of whom rose from immigrant beginnings, were selected yesterday as the first recipients of the Medal of Liberty, to be presented at the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration this summer.   The...

byline.original: By SARA RIMER

results.lead_paragraph: Twelve prominent Americans, 11 men and 1 woman, all of whom rose from immigrant beginnings, were selected yesterday as the first recipients of the Medal of Liberty, to be presented at the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration this summer. The winners were announced by Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation and of the Chrysler Corporation. ''We think they're a distinguished group,'' he said at a news conference in the Hunt Room of the ''21'' Club. ''They came to the land of opportunity and made it big.''

headline.main: TEXAS AIR COMES TO EASTERN'S AID

results.snippet: Texas Air's $600 million bid for Eastern shook up the passenger carrier industry and carries long-term implications for the post-deregulation era. Frank Lorenzo, Texas Air's chairman, is aiming to build a major route system by combining Eastern's...

byline.original: By Merrill Perlman

results.lead_paragraph: Texas Air's $600 million bid for Eastern shook up the passenger carrier industry and carries long-term implications for the post-deregulation era. Frank Lorenzo, Texas Air's chairman, is aiming to build a major route system by combining Eastern's modern fleet with his smaller Continental and New York Air operations. That would probably require him to divest some of the Washington-New York-Boston shuttle routes that New York Air has been working to build against Eastern's shuttle. But the cost-cutting for which Mr. Lorenzo has become known in the industry promises continued fare competition. Eastern was pressured into the sale by its creditors - who loaned it the money to modernize - and its unions. The unions, which represent half the carrier's workers, own about 20 percent of Eastern, which they got in return for past concessions. They have balked at further cuts, saying Eastern's chairman, Frank Borman, is looking in the wrong place. Creditors, meanwhile, say the carrier still must get more concessions or they will force it to default. Mr. Borman is hoping Texas Air will help Eastern out of the muddle. Although the unions say the deal is ill-advised, and seek Mr. Borman's ouster, Mr. Lorenzo said he will keep the former astronaut on board - for now.

headline.main: SPACE TRIP IS STILL ASTRONAUTS' GOAL

results.snippet: The pilot of the last successful space shuttle mission said today that despite recent disclosures of communications breakdowns among space agency managers before the Challenger flight, he knows of no astronauts planning to quit the shuttle program....

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The pilot of the last successful space shuttle mission said today that despite recent disclosures of communications breakdowns among space agency managers before the Challenger flight, he knows of no astronauts planning to quit the shuttle program. ''Even as we continue the investigation, the big thing is to keep people encouraged, to let them know that at least the guys in the program have no intention of quitting,'' the pilot, Lieut. Col. Charles F. Bolden Jr. of the Marine Corps, said in an interview. His comments came as the 95 full-time members of the nation's astronaut corps began resuming public appearances after a monthlong self-imposed silence about the explosion Jan. 28 of the Challenger, which killed seven of their colleagues. Colonel Bolden said he was not surprised by reports of problems with the joints of the shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets, which are suspected as a major cause of the explosion.

headline.main: NEWS SUMMARY

results.snippet: MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1986 International Restoration of Filipino human rights began with President Corazon C. Aquino's ''Proclamation No.1'' restoring the writ of habeas corpus. She said new government structures would be formed to hear and act on...
results.lead_paragraph: MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1986 International Restoration of Filipino human rights began with President Corazon C. Aquino's ''Proclamation No.1'' restoring the writ of habeas corpus. She said new government structures would be formed to hear and act on recommendations and complaints of citizens. [ Page A1, Column 6. ] A West Bank Mayor was shot dead as he was walking from his home to City Hall. A spokesman for the Israeli Civil Administration in the occupied territories said Mayor Zafer el-Masri of Nablus, a Palestinian appointed by Israel who was regarded as an alternative to the slogans of the Palestine Liberation Organization, had been killed by a single assailant. The central area of Nablus was under curfew, and access to the city was blocked by the Israeli army. [ A1:2. ] Palestinians in Israel-occupied land say they have been stunned, dismayed and frightened by the rupture in the yearlong effort by King Hussein and Yasir Arafat to devise a joint position on Middle East talks. Palestinians living in the West Bank and Gaza Strip say they were even more disconcerted by King Hussein's call on them last week to decide who should lead them. [ A3:1. ] A cut in Brazil's interest rate on nearly a third of the country's foreign debt was agreed on by a group of international banks which made $31 billion in loans. The agreement was reached Saturday night after about a month of negotiations and a day after President Jose Sarney ordered sweeping economic changes to combat Brazil's soaring inflation.

headline.main: ASTRONAUT ASSAILS NASA FOR NOT TELLING OF RISK

results.snippet: HOUSTON, March 3 - A senior astronaut said today he was very upset that he and other astronauts were not informed that the space shuttle had a chronic problem with seals on its booster rockets.   Henry W. Hartsfield Jr., who has flown three shuttle...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, March 3 - A senior astronaut said today he was very upset that he and other astronauts were not informed that the space shuttle had a chronic problem with seals on its booster rockets. Henry W. Hartsfield Jr., who has flown three shuttle missions, two as commander, said it was ''amazing'' that crews were left unaware even after seal problems had been detected in 12 of the 24 previous shuttle flights and a committee had been formed to consider redesigns. ''I am very much upset we did not know about it,'' he said ''It caught me completely by surprise.'' Trouble with the O-ring seals on the solid-fuel booster rockets is now regarded as the chief suspect in the explosion that destroyed the shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, killing all seven crew members.

headline.main: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 4, 1986

results.snippet: International    The new Manila Government moved in Federal District Court in Hawaii to recover millions of dollars in currency taken by Ferdinand E. Marcos and and his party when they left the country last week. Lawyers representing the United...
results.lead_paragraph: International The new Manila Government moved in Federal District Court in Hawaii to recover millions of dollars in currency taken by Ferdinand E. Marcos and and his party when they left the country last week. Lawyers representing the United States pledged to provide the Philippines Central Bank with an accounting of the currency contained in 22 crates that were flown to Hawaii. [ Page A1, Column 6. ] Corazon C. Aquino was hailed as the Philippines's de facto President by the leaders of the National Assembly majority that had pronounced her the electoral loser only two weeks ago. The legislators stressed their willingness to ''extend all kinds of cooperation'' to Mrs. Aquino. [ A12:3-5. ]

headline.main: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MARCH 9, 1986

results.snippet: International    A compromise with Congress on aid for the Nicaraguan rebels is now sought by the Reagan Administration, which faces defeat on Capitol Hill over its $100 million proposal for the anti-Sandinistas. However, the Administration's...
results.lead_paragraph: International A compromise with Congress on aid for the Nicaraguan rebels is now sought by the Reagan Administration, which faces defeat on Capitol Hill over its $100 million proposal for the anti-Sandinistas. However, the Administration's intense public campaign to win support for the program was continued by President Reagan in his weekly radio speech. [ Page 1, Column 1. ]

headline.main: SHUTTLE INQUIRERS TAKING NEW TACK

results.snippet: Investigators pursuing the causes of the space shuttle disaster believe that the major disclosures about equipment failures and management decisions have largely been made public, people familiar with the investigation said today.   Now, these...

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Investigators pursuing the causes of the space shuttle disaster believe that the major disclosures about equipment failures and management decisions have largely been made public, people familiar with the investigation said today. Now, these sources contend, the Presidential commission is preparing to open a new phase of the inquiry. It will focus on an increasingly complicated set of technical issues surrounding joints in the right-hand booster rocket of the Challenger craft and unresolved questions related to possible financial or other pressures on the space agency to sustain an ambitious launching schedule. As the panel completed a week of closed and public hearings at the Kennedy Space Center, it had crossed many items off a long list of potential causes for the accident, including the shuttle orbiter and the main engines.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS' CHIEF SAYS NASA RISKED LIFE FOR SCHEDULE

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has exposed astronauts to numerous potentially ''catastrophic'' hazards because of pressure to maintain its launching schedule, the chief of the agency's astronaut office has asserted.   The...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has exposed astronauts to numerous potentially ''catastrophic'' hazards because of pressure to maintain its launching schedule, the chief of the agency's astronaut office has asserted. The official, John W. Young, made the complaints in two internal memorandums dated March 4, after a Presidential panel investigating the Jan. 28 explosion of the shuttle Challenger heard extensive testimony criticizing NASA's decision-making procedures. In an enclosure Mr. Young gave what he called an ''awesome'' list of safety-related problems that he said ''ought to be fixed so that we do not lose any more space shuttles and flight crews.'' 'Some Very Lucky People' ''Many of these potentially serious conditions were discovered after we started operating,'' Mr. Young, a veteran astronaut, wrote. ''On an individual basis, they were not big enough to slow or stop the launch rates. But totally, this list is awesome. The list proves to me that there are some very lucky people around here.''

headline.main: EXCERPTS FROM SHUTTLE MEMORANDUM BY ASTRONAUTS' CHIEF

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from a memorandum released here today that was written by John W. Young, chief of the astronaut office of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which accompanied an ''enclosure'' listing what he says are routine...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a memorandum released here today that was written by John W. Young, chief of the astronaut office of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which accompanied an ''enclosure'' listing what he says are routine but dangerous conditions in the space shuttle program. The enclosure lists some conditions and events that are present in the space shuttle program at this time. These are not all the conditions of serious concern. These situations increase, to some unquantifiable and unassessable extent, the space shuttle program, the space shuttle, and the flight crew risk. I have talked to individuals - working level and mid-level engineers, operators, and managers - who are seriously concerned about each of these accepted situations in their areas of specialty. These accepted conditions could have been or are now potentially as catastrophic to the space shuttle program as the 51-L accident.

headline.main: AGAINST THE IDEA OF 'ELITIST' SCHOOLS

results.snippet: Three cheers for Dr. Richard Doremus's article, ''Do We Really Need a Science High School?''  [ Opinion Page, Feb. 9 ] . As the parent of a third- grader currently enrolled in our local Syosset public school and also attending a program for gifted...
results.section_name: Technology; Science; Education; New York and Region; Opinion
results.lead_paragraph: Three cheers for Dr. Richard Doremus's article, ''Do We Really Need a Science High School?'' [ Opinion Page, Feb. 9 ] . As the parent of a third- grader currently enrolled in our local Syosset public school and also attending a program for gifted elementary youngsters in the same school, I agree with Dr. Doremus that Governor Cuomo is advocating the worst possible course of action for the science education of Long Island's students.

headline.main: QUOTATION OF THE DAY

results.snippet: ''If the management system is not big enough to stop the space shuttle program whenever necessary to make flight safety corrections, it will not survive and neither will our three space shuttles or their flight crews.'' - John W. Young, chief of...
results.lead_paragraph: ''If the management system is not big enough to stop the space shuttle program whenever necessary to make flight safety corrections, it will not survive and neither will our three space shuttles or their flight crews.'' - John W. Young, chief of the astronaut office of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. [ 1:6. ]

headline.main: AGENCY REBUTS TOP ASTRONAUT ON SAFETY RISK

results.snippet: Top space agency officials took sharp exception yesterday to charges by the agency's chief astronaut that shuttle crews have been repeatedly exposed to potentially ''catastrophic'' hazards because of pressures to maintain launching schedules.  ...

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER

results.lead_paragraph: Top space agency officials took sharp exception yesterday to charges by the agency's chief astronaut that shuttle crews have been repeatedly exposed to potentially ''catastrophic'' hazards because of pressures to maintain launching schedules. Safety experts at the agency said that the most critical items on a long list of concerns raised in a memorandum by John W. Young, the head of the agency's astronaut office, were identified long ago. The experts said that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has worked diligently to correct them. No safety concerns, the officials said, were being ignored to preserve a schedule.

headline.kicker: MAN IN THE NEWS: ROALD ZINNUROVICH SAGDEYEV
headline.main: RUSSIAN WHO PEERED INTO HALLEY'S

results.snippet: Not long after his graduation from Moscow State University in 1955, Roald Z. Sagdeyev attended a Geneva conference on atomic energy and met American scientists for the first time. ''It was 30 years ago,'' Mr. Sagdeyev, the physicist who heads the...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Not long after his graduation from Moscow State University in 1955, Roald Z. Sagdeyev attended a Geneva conference on atomic energy and met American scientists for the first time. ''It was 30 years ago,'' Mr. Sagdeyev, the physicist who heads the Space Research Institute, said last week. ''I was very young. I was looking at them as extraterrestrials,'' Barely pausing, he added, ''Throughout my career, I felt very close to my American colleagues.'' For Mr. Sagdeyev, the Americans are extraterrestrials no more. He is more than comfortable looking them in the eye.

headline.main: DEAD ARE ABOARD

results.snippet: Navy divers have found the crew compartment of the space shuttle Challenger, containing remains of the astronauts who died after the craft exploded high above the Atlantic 40 days ago, space agency officials said today.   Efforts were under way...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Navy divers have found the crew compartment of the space shuttle Challenger, containing remains of the astronauts who died after the craft exploded high above the Atlantic 40 days ago, space agency officials said today. Efforts were under way tonight to retrieve the cabin debris, which is resting in 100 feet of water about 15 miles northeast of here, and to return the remains for positive identification, the officials said. Late tonight, a Navy spokesman would neither confirm nor deny reports that some of the astronauts' remains had been brought ashore. Families Were Notified ''On Saturday morning, after securing operations during the night for safety reasons, the U.S.S. Preserver, whose divers are thoroughly briefed on debris identification and who have participated in similar recovery operations, began to work,'' the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said in a statement issued here today. ''Subsequent dives provided positive identification of Challenger crew compartment debris and the existence of crew remains.''

headline.main: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1986

results.snippet: International A French political realignment is expected to result from next week's legislative elections. But the larger change may be that France, in the five years since the Socialist Government came to power, has become more like other...
results.lead_paragraph: International A French political realignment is expected to result from next week's legislative elections. But the larger change may be that France, in the five years since the Socialist Government came to power, has become more like other democracies. Surveys have shown a tendency for the French to abandon traditional antagonisms and move toward a broad consensus. As a result, alternating governments of the right and the left are possible. [ Page A1, Column 1. ] Another view of Halley's comet was obtained from close-up. Data gathered by Vega 2, the second of the Soviet Union's two unmanned missions to the comet, apparently confirmed theories that the comet's elliptical nucleus is solid. [ A1:5. ]

headline.kicker: TALKING BUSINESS WITH CIPRIANO OF SPACE ROUNDTABLE
headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE AND COMMERCE

results.snippet: The outlook for commercial ventures in space, already clouded by insurance problems, became hazier as a result of the Jan. 28 space shuttle disaster. For telecommunications executives or those hoping to develop products in the weightless conditions...

byline.original: By BARNABY J. FEDER

results.lead_paragraph: The outlook for commercial ventures in space, already clouded by insurance problems, became hazier as a result of the Jan. 28 space shuttle disaster. For telecommunications executives or those hoping to develop products in the weightless conditions of space, questions about what caused the Challenger explosion are bound up with worries about when the shuttles may fly again. Anthony J. Cipriano is chairman of the Space Commerce Roundtable Foundation, established last October by the New York Society of Securities Analysts, the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, the Financial Women's Association of New York and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. The foundation grew out of five years of informal meetings by these groups as they followed the progress of commercial space ventures. Q. When do you see flights resuming? A. We are most likely looking at a year's delay, depending on what actions are taken to correct the most glaring problem - the seam between the fuel cell and the engine. There are 40 solutions under consideration. Whether it was the cause of the accident or not, we know that has to be fixed.

headline.main: KIN GIVEN HOPE SHUTTLE BODIES ARE IDENTIFIABLE

results.snippet: The crew compartment and the remains of the Challenger astronauts were not intact when discovered, family members reported today, but one relative said officials believed some identifications were still possible.   Another relative, Francis W....

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The crew compartment and the remains of the Challenger astronauts were not intact when discovered, family members reported today, but one relative said officials believed some identifications were still possible. Another relative, Francis W. Scobee, father of the shuttle's commander, Francis R. Scobee, said he had been told that some remains had already been brought to the surface for examination. Mr. Scobee said the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had told him divers were planning to search for more remains. Dr. Marvin Resnik, father of another crew member, Dr. Judith A. Resnik, said the agency believed that some of the bodies could be identified despite decomposition. Compartment Ruptured Carl McNair, whose son Dr. Ronald E. McNair died in the explosion Jan. 28, said at a public appearance in New York today that he was told this morning by a representative of the space agency that the crew compartment had been ruptured. He said the remains were clearly visible to divers peering into the sunken compartment.

headline.main: Did Crew Die Instantly? Questions Re-emerging

results.snippet: Questions about how much the Challenger's crew knew about the danger they faced were re-emerging today after the discovery of wreckage of the space shuttle's cabin.   Among the questions are whether the five men and two women aboard died instantly,...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Questions about how much the Challenger's crew knew about the danger they faced were re-emerging today after the discovery of wreckage of the space shuttle's cabin. Among the questions are whether the five men and two women aboard died instantly, without warning, in the fireball that engulfed the Challenger 74 seconds after liftoff Jan. 28, or whether they were aware in those final terrifying seconds that their ship was breaking apart. An astronaut, speaking on the condition that he not be identified, said today that as the shuttle ascended ''an auditory and warning light may have come on, but by the time they could have done anything, the ship was disintegrating.'' The stark visual impression was that everything was going smoothly until the spacecraft suddenly, and without warning, vaporized. This impression was reinforced by the absence of any frantic, last-minute transmissions from the shuttle.

headline.main: EFFORT RESUMES TO RECOVER SHUTTLE CABIN

results.snippet: The space agency resumed its efforts today to recover the broken crew compartment of the space shuttle Challenger so that forensic experts can identify the decomposed remains of the astronauts that have been discovered inside.   Lieut. Comdr....

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space agency resumed its efforts today to recover the broken crew compartment of the space shuttle Challenger so that forensic experts can identify the decomposed remains of the astronauts that have been discovered inside. Lieut. Comdr. Deborah A. Burnette of the Navy, a spokesman for salvage operations, said weather conditions over the site had improved today, enabling Navy ships to deploy divers to inspect wreckage from the compartment. Eight-foot seas and strong winds on Monday had forced salvage experts to abandon their search of the wreckage, which was is in about 100 feet of water, 16 miles off the Florida coast.

headline.main: NASA WOULD SHIFT SOME LAUNCHINGS TO PRIVATE SECTOR

results.snippet: The space agency has decided on a major revision of its space operations by shifting to a mixed fleet of shuttles and unmanned rockets to launch earth satellites, officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration confirmed yesterday.  ...

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER

results.lead_paragraph: The space agency has decided on a major revision of its space operations by shifting to a mixed fleet of shuttles and unmanned rockets to launch earth satellites, officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration confirmed yesterday. Under a new policy, prompted by a Federal interagency group in the six weeks since the explosion of the Challenger shuttle, the space agency will move to encourage private space companies to launch satellites that previously would have been sent aloft by the space shuttles. Until the Jan. 28 explosion of the shuttle, with the loss of seven crew members, the space agency had consistently opposed using expendable unmanned rockets to put military and commercial satellites in orbit, saying its four shuttles were the best and most competitive vehicles for that purpose. 'Consensus Is Emerging' But in a memorandum to Richard Truly, the new director of shuttle operations, William R. Graham, NASA's Acting Administrator, wrote last Friday that ''a consensus is emerging'' within the Reagan Administration to rely increasingly on the unmanned rockets, known as expendable launch vehicles.

headline.main: The Astronauts' Fear of Flying

results.snippet: Fear and outrage have appeared in the corps of astronauts. John Young, the chief astronaut, has chided NASA for putting schedule above safety. Sally Ride, one of the shuttle crash investigators, says she's not ready to fly again. In the darkness of...
results.lead_paragraph: Fear and outrage have appeared in the corps of astronauts. John Young, the chief astronaut, has chided NASA for putting schedule above safety. Sally Ride, one of the shuttle crash investigators, says she's not ready to fly again. In the darkness of space, astronauts know no fear. What terrifies them is their glimpse of NASA's decision-making.

headline.main: NASA SHIFT MAY BE BOON TO ROCKET INDUSTRY

results.snippet: The space agency's decision to let the private rocket industry supplement the shuttle in lofting satellites gives this struggling business its best chance yet to develop the nation's first commercially run launching apparatus, analysts and...

byline.original: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space agency's decision to let the private rocket industry supplement the shuttle in lofting satellites gives this struggling business its best chance yet to develop the nation's first commercially run launching apparatus, analysts and executives said today. For several years, private launching companies, which under the new policy would send up communications satellites on unmanned rockets, have been battling opposition from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which argued they were superfluous. But with the Jan. 28 loss of the Challenger, the space agency has come to what analysts have called an inevitable conclusion: Without this industry, the shuttle capacity would not be enough to send aloft a growing list of private satellites. The policy shift was confirmed by the space agency on Tuesday. The private companies, however, will not be ready to launch for at least two years. While France and other nations pushed ahead with unmanned launching technology, the American unmanned rocket program has been nearly dormant and it will take that long to build the rockets and make the other arrangements necessary for a launching. Even then, the experts say, unmanned rockets will have a limited ability to replace the space shuttle.

headline.main: LIFTING SOVIET SECRECY

results.snippet: News Analysis The Soviet Union, breaking with tradition by showing a new openness about its space program, announced yesterday that astronauts were preparing for an earth-orbiting mission to be launched today. They were expected to occupy a new...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

results.lead_paragraph: News Analysis The Soviet Union, breaking with tradition by showing a new openness about its space program, announced yesterday that astronauts were preparing for an earth-orbiting mission to be launched today. They were expected to occupy a new Soviet space station. Soviet manned space flights have almost always been announced only after they were successfully launched. One exception, which occurred in an unusual context, was when Soviet astronauts took off in a Soyuz spacecraft to rendezvous with American astronauts in an Apollo craft in 1975. Launchings of flights that carried French and Indian crew members were televised live.

headline.main: SHULMAN ELECTED TO SUCCEED MANES

results.snippet: Claire Shulman was unanimously elected Borough President of Queens yesterday in a special vote by the borough's nine City Council members.   Mrs. Shulman, who had been Deputy Borough President since 1980, succeeds Donald R. Manes. He resigned last...

byline.original: By FRANK LYNN

results.lead_paragraph: Claire Shulman was unanimously elected Borough President of Queens yesterday in a special vote by the borough's nine City Council members. Mrs. Shulman, who had been Deputy Borough President since 1980, succeeds Donald R. Manes. He resigned last month after an apparent suicide attempt and investigations into allegations of extortion involving collection agencies under contract to the Parking Violations Bureau. The first woman in the post, Mrs. Shulman will serve until the end of the year and would not commit herself to seeking election in November to the remaining three years of Mr. Manes's term.

headline.main: EXAMINATION OF REMAINS SHIFTS TO NASA LAB

results.snippet: Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that efforts to identify the remains of the seven Challenger astronauts would be conducted at a secluded, high-technology space agency laboratory here.   Since the first...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that efforts to identify the remains of the seven Challenger astronauts would be conducted at a secluded, high-technology space agency laboratory here. Since the first remains were recovered last weekend, the work had been done at Patrick Air Force Base about 25 miles south of the space center. On Wednesday night the Navy recovery ship that had found the crew compartment of the Challenger slipped quietly into port, and with solemn ceremony containers from the ship were transferred to shore. As honor guards stood watch, sailors wearing dress uniforms unloaded the material that had been lifted from the crew cabin of the Challenger, and about 30 minutes later a convoy of ambulances sped off, lights flashing.

headline.main: AGE OF SPACE: A SOVIET STEP

results.snippet: Two Soviet astronauts were launched into orbit yesterday, bound for a large facility the Russians call Mir in a move seen by many space experts as the beginning of the age of the space station.   Their mission could well mark the start of the time...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

results.lead_paragraph: Two Soviet astronauts were launched into orbit yesterday, bound for a large facility the Russians call Mir in a move seen by many space experts as the beginning of the age of the space station. Their mission could well mark the start of the time when humans take up a more or less permanent occupation of space. If all goes well when the astronauts reach the orbiting station, scheduled for Saturday, they would get to work preparing the Mir to serve as the core for an assortment of modules to be attached later and thus provide ample working space for a variety of activities in biology, materials processing, astrophysics and earth observation, according to American authorities on the Soviet space program. Launching Is Telecast All appeared to go well with the launching, which was telecast live throughout the Soviet Union. [ Page A16. ] The American experts described the Mir as a ''major advance'' over the experimental Salyut stations that the Soviet Union has used for nearly 15 years in demonstrating the ability of humans to live and work for long periods in orbit, up to nine months. Soviet officials themselves have said that the Mir marks ''the beginning of a transition from research and experiments to large-scale production activities in outer space.''

headline.main: F.A.A. INSPECTORS' REPORT ON CONTINENTAL AIRLINES' SAFETY WAS ALTERED, THEY TESTIFY

results.snippet: Two retired air safety inspectors for the Federal Aviation Administration accused superiors today of covering up findings of safety and training violations at Continental Airlines.   They told a Senate investigating panel that a critical report...

byline.original: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Two retired air safety inspectors for the Federal Aviation Administration accused superiors today of covering up findings of safety and training violations at Continental Airlines. They told a Senate investigating panel that a critical report they prepared in 1984 had been withheld and altered to put ''a more favorable light'' on the aviation agency and the airline, which was then going through a bitter strike by its pilots and a bankruptcy reorganization. Defending the handling of the report, Anthony J. Broderick, the agency's associate administrator for aviation standards, testified that he had ordered the Continental inspection report rewritten ''to remove unwarranted and unsubstantiated'' findings. He contended that none of the violations found had been stricken from a version put out later.

headline.main: 2 SOVIET ASTRONAUTS LOFTED TOWARD NEW SPACE STATION

results.snippet: The Soviet Union launched two astronauts today toward a rendezvous with the new space station Mir, and in a rare move the takeoff was shown live on national television.   At exactly 3:33 P.M. (7:33 A.M., New York time), flames belched from the huge...

byline.original: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union launched two astronauts today toward a rendezvous with the new space station Mir, and in a rare move the takeoff was shown live on national television. At exactly 3:33 P.M. (7:33 A.M., New York time), flames belched from the huge boosters and the rocket lifted smoothly over the snow-dappled Central Asian steppes at the Baikonur launching site. Fifty seconds later, as the voice of the controller reported that ''the flight is normal,'' the television shifted to cameras inside the Soyuz T-15 craft and showed Col. Leonid D. Kizim, the commander, and Vladimir Solovyov, the flight engineer, cradled in their space suits and apparently at ease. At 120 seconds, as the controller announced the separation of the first stage, the astronauts were visibly jolted. The transmission continued until the 270th second, when the crew was reported safely in orbit.

headline.main: SOVIET ASTRONAUTS ON SPACE STATION

results.snippet: Two Soviet astronauts today boarded the new Soviet space station that is expected to become the first permanently manned orbiting laboratory.   Tass, the Government press agency, announced that the spaceship Soyuz T-15 carrying Col. Leonid D. Kizim...

byline.original: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Two Soviet astronauts today boarded the new Soviet space station that is expected to become the first permanently manned orbiting laboratory. Tass, the Government press agency, announced that the spaceship Soyuz T-15 carrying Col. Leonid D. Kizim and Vladimir A. Solovyev, the flight engineer, docked at 4:38 P.M. with the Mir station, whose name means peace in Russian. The evening television news program showed the two astronauts laughing and frolicking in the spacious cabin of the Mir soon after boarding, and proudly showing off its trappings with a hand-held television camera. As the telecast opened, Colonel Kizim seemed to be doing a somersault, while a laughing Mr. Solovyev told the mission controllers, ''So, are you convinced now that we're here?'' Light-Hearted Broadcast The interview continued with a gaiety and lightness unusual for Soviet space broadcasts, and the astronauts appeared to be genuinely excited about the new station. Colonel Kizim and Mr. Solovyev, along with another astronaut, Dr. Oleg Atkov, had spent a record of 238 days in space aboard the Salyut-7 orbiting lab, a station considerably more cramped than the Mir.

headline.main: A DUTCHMAN'S QUEST FOR A BLACK TULIP

results.snippet: A black tulip, flowering at midnight, sounds like something from an old Dutch fairy tale. But it happened in the tiny village (pop. 300) of Oude Niedorp, a one-windmill town about 35 miles northwest of Amsterdam. And after a month of newspaper and...

byline.original: By ALICE FURLAUD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A black tulip, flowering at midnight, sounds like something from an old Dutch fairy tale. But it happened in the tiny village (pop. 300) of Oude Niedorp, a one-windmill town about 35 miles northwest of Amsterdam. And after a month of newspaper and television interviews, Geert Hageman, the 29-year-old horticulturist who developed the new black tulip, is still euphoric about this somber variety of his national flower. A tulip of this hue is exceedingly rare, and in the Netherlands, where about $150 million worth of tulip bulbs and $100 million in cut tulips are produced a year, the tulip's potential profits are significant. ''It was about 12:30 on Feb. 18th,'' Mr. Hageman recounted. ''I had already looked once or twice at this group of tulips, and then I saw it. I couldn't tell anybody - my wife was sleeping - so I walked around drinking a beer. The next morning I took the tulip in to the West Frisian Flora show at Bovenkarspel.'' At this event, the Netherlands' most prestigious bulb-flower display, his tulip was a show stopper. That night Mr. Hageman, a tall man with an innocent and sturdy gaze, appeared on his first television show.

headline.main: ROCKET COMPANY STOPPED TEST FIRINGS ON JAN. 28

results.snippet: The company that provides the space shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets is using small-scale models of booster parts to test the design of joints suspected of causing the Challenger disaster, a spokesman said today.   Members of an independent...

byline.original: AP

results.lead_paragraph: The company that provides the space shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets is using small-scale models of booster parts to test the design of joints suspected of causing the Challenger disaster, a spokesman said today. Members of an independent panel of rocket experts arrived at the Morton Thiokol's Wasatch Division plant today to begin evaluating the tests on the design of the O rings that seal the joints of the booster rockets. The tests include firing small-scale rocket motors in order to subject scaled-down cross-sections of booster segments to conditions similar to those the full-size rockets experienced the day the Challenger blew up with its crew of seven, said a company spokesman, Gil Moore.

headline.main: NAVY AND NASA TO ADD 2 SHIPS AND SUBMERSIBLE TO SHUTTLE SEARCH

results.snippet: The space agency and the Navy have decided to add two more surface ships and one more manned submersible vehicle to step up the search for wreckage of the space shuttle Challenger.   James R. Thompson Jr., a high-ranking official of the National...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space agency and the Navy have decided to add two more surface ships and one more manned submersible vehicle to step up the search for wreckage of the space shuttle Challenger. James R. Thompson Jr., a high-ranking official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, says the Presidential commission looking into the disaster has asked the agency to complete its investigation, including salvage work, by April 18. The commission, which is to reconvene public hearings Friday in Washington, must report to President Reagan by June 3. The addition of the ocean research ship Edwin Link and the Navy auxiliary submarine rescue ship Kittiwake next week will bring to 12 the surface ships seeking to recover key pieces of wreckage from the spacecraft, which exploded over the ocean Jan. 28, killing the seven astronauts aboard.

headline.main: MILITARY MISSIONS TO DOMINATE ROLE OF SPACE SHUTTLE

results.snippet: In an important shift, the space agency is planning to devote most space shuttle flights to military missions once launchings resume, senior officials say.   Even before the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has fully identified and...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

results.lead_paragraph: In an important shift, the space agency is planning to devote most space shuttle flights to military missions once launchings resume, senior officials say. Even before the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has fully identified and corrected the problem that caused the space shuttle Challenger to explode, officials are planning an ambitious series of missions next year. Senior agency officials said in interviews that up to nine shuttle launchings are tentatively scheduled, including one from a military base in California. Five to seven of the flights are devoted to the military, depending on how particular payloads are defined. The Mix Is Shifting Officials emphasized that there would be no shuttle launchings until the problem that destroyed the Challenger and killed its seven crew members had been discovered and fixed.

headline.main: SETTLEMENTS ON MOON AND MARS PROPOSED BY PANEL

results.snippet: A Presidential panel is proposing a long-range, $700 billion space program that would put manned settlements on the moon in 30 years and envisions an eventual 1 million space travelers a day, according to a published report.   The National...

byline.original: AP

results.lead_paragraph: A Presidential panel is proposing a long-range, $700 billion space program that would put manned settlements on the moon in 30 years and envisions an eventual 1 million space travelers a day, according to a published report. The National Commission on Space, appointed by President Reagan a year ago, is to present the White House next month with a report setting forth an ambitious 50-year space program, Aviation Week and Space Technology reports in its March 24 issue. Under the commission's plan, new spacecraft would place settlements on the moon and Mars, where they would be sustained by interplanetary factories and permanant supply depots, says Aviation Week. The authoritative magazine obtained a final draft of the panel's report.

headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE FLIGHTS TO RESUME UNDER STRICT RULES, OFFICIAL SAYS

results.snippet: The new director of the space shuttle program said today that flights would resume under extremely conservative rules, and he asserted that such an approach would not impede the nation's space endeavors.   The director, Adm. Richard H. Truly, said...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The new director of the space shuttle program said today that flights would resume under extremely conservative rules, and he asserted that such an approach would not impede the nation's space endeavors. The director, Adm. Richard H. Truly, said the first flight, not yet scheduled, would be launched only in daylight and in warm weather. It would carry only astronauts and would not land at Cape Canaveral, Fla., where weather is more of a concern than in California.

headline.main: SEVEN ASTEROIDS ARE NAMED FOR CREW OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE

results.snippet: Seven recently discovered asteroids were named yesterday for the seven astronauts who died in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.   The asteroids, which were discovered by the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Ariz., from 1980 to 1984,...

byline.original: By WALTER SULLIVAN

results.lead_paragraph: Seven recently discovered asteroids were named yesterday for the seven astronauts who died in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. The asteroids, which were discovered by the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Ariz., from 1980 to 1984, are believed to be from 5 to 10 miles in diameter. The Central Bureau for Astronomical Telegrams of the International Astronomical Union yesterday notified observatories around the world of the new names. The bureau is at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory in Cambridge, Mass.

headline.main: CHILDREN'S LETTERS VOICE SORROW ABOUT ASTRONAUTS WHO DIED

results.snippet: ''Dear Mr. McAuliffe,'' one child wrote to the husband of Christa McAuliffe, ''I'm very sorry that you lost your wife. I was watching the news and I saw your children say, 'Don't go, Mom,' and I'm sure they are very unhappy. I wish I could help you...

byline.original: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

results.lead_paragraph: ''Dear Mr. McAuliffe,'' one child wrote to the husband of Christa McAuliffe, ''I'm very sorry that you lost your wife. I was watching the news and I saw your children say, 'Don't go, Mom,' and I'm sure they are very unhappy. I wish I could help you and your family. Sincerely yours, Mike Bonanno.'' Mental health experts say this letter and thousands like it show that many children experienced the death of Christa McAuliffe, the schoolteacher-astronaut, as the symbolic loss of a mother and that they may have been more deeply disturbed by this loss than they let on otherwise. The very act of writing the letters was a way for many children to heal emotional wounds, the experts say.

headline.main: Military Memories For Queens Leader

results.snippet: Two weeks after her election as Borough President of Queens, Claire Shulman crossed the border into Brooklyn to address an audience drawn from around the country - the United States Navy.   Mrs. Shulman was the main speaker last Thursday at an...

byline.original: By Susan Heller Anderson and David W. Dunlap

results.lead_paragraph: Two weeks after her election as Borough President of Queens, Claire Shulman crossed the border into Brooklyn to address an audience drawn from around the country - the United States Navy. Mrs. Shulman was the main speaker last Thursday at an observance of Women's History Month by the New York Naval Station, in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
